title: Primary CNS Lymphoma (PCNSL), Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma Confined to the CNS
scope: ** Comprehensive management of newly diagnosed and recurrent primary CNS lymphoma (PCNSL) in immunocompetent and immunocompromised (HIV/AIDS, post-transplant) adults. Covers initial presentation and stabilization, neuroimaging evaluation (MRI with gadolinium, diffusion-weighted imaging), the critical importance of avoiding corticosteroids before biopsy, stereotactic brain biopsy, CSF analysis (cytology, flow cytometry), slit lamp ophthalmologic examination, systemic staging (whole body CT/PET, bone marrow biopsy, testicular ultrasound in males), high-dose methotrexate (HD-MTX)-based induction chemotherapy, rituximab, consolidation strategies (whole brain radiation therapy, high-dose chemotherapy with autologous stem cell transplant, cytarabine-based consolidation), management of relapsed/refractory disease, HIV-associated PCNSL management (ART initiation, modified chemotherapy), and supportive care. Excludes secondary CNS involvement from systemic lymphoma, primary vitreoretinal lymphoma as sole presentation (overlapping but managed differently), and pediatric PCNSL.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline before chemotherapy; assess for cytopenias; lymphocyte count for immune status; platelet count for biopsy candidacy
Essential/Core Labs.target: WBC, ANC, platelets within normal limits; ALC for baseline immune function

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Renal function critical for methotrexate dosing (excreted renally); hepatic function for chemotherapy clearance; electrolytes for SIADH screening; glucose baseline for steroid use
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal renal function (CrCl >50 mL/min required for HD-MTX); normal LFTs

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Tumor burden and prognostic marker; elevated LDH is adverse prognostic factor in IELSG scoring system
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; elevated suggests higher tumor burden

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Coagulopathy assessment for biopsy candidacy; baseline before procedures
Baseline before corticosteroids (if used post-biopsy); pre-operative assessment
HIV-associated PCNSL occurs in severely immunocompromised patients (CD4 <50); dramatically alters treatment approach; EBV-driven lymphomagenesis in HIV
Essential/Core Labs.target: Negative; if positive proceed to CD4 count and viral load

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Rituximab can cause fatal HBV reactivation; mandatory screening before anti-CD20 therapy
Essential/Core Labs.target: Negative; if positive consult hepatology for antiviral prophylaxis before rituximab

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline hepatic risk assessment before hepatotoxic chemotherapy
Tumor lysis syndrome risk (high-grade lymphoma); baseline before chemotherapy initiation
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; elevated requires prophylaxis with allopurinol or rasburicase

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Methotrexate is abortifacient and teratogenic; rituximab is pregnancy category C; radiation contraindicated
Pre-biopsy; anticipate possible intraoperative blood loss
Evaluate for monoclonal protein; rule out Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia or myeloma with CNS involvement

Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Document CD4; <200 requires PJP prophylaxis; <50 typical for HIV-PCNSL

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Baseline for ART management; high viral load correlates with PCNSL risk
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Quantify; goal is undetectable on ART

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: EBV drives HIV-associated PCNSL; EBV viral load correlates with disease activity; can be used for monitoring
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Positive EBV in immunocompromised = supports PCNSL diagnosis; negative does not exclude

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Baseline humoral immunity before rituximab (depletes B cells); hypogammaglobulinemia risk assessment
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Normal; low IgG increases infection risk during treatment

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Prognostic marker; component of some PCNSL prognostic scoring systems; elevated correlates with tumor burden
Baseline thyroid function before radiation therapy (hypothyroidism risk with WBRT); fatigue differential
If hypothalamic/pituitary involvement suspected; adrenal function if prior steroids
Precise renal function assessment critical for methotrexate dosing; CrCl >50 mL/min required for HD-MTX
If syncope or seizure presentation; cardiac evaluation before chemotherapy
HIV-positive patients: toxoplasmosis is the main differential for ring-enhancing lesions; positive IgG + compatible imaging = empiric treatment trial before biopsy
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Negative supports PCNSL over toxoplasmosis; positive requires empiric treatment trial

Present in ~70-80% of PCNSL; supports diagnosis when tissue is limited; emerging biomarker for monitoring treatment response

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Elevated ICP from mass effect; baseline for serial monitoring
Lumbar Puncture.target: 10-20 cm H2O; elevated with significant mass effect

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Lymphocytic pleocytosis common in PCNSL; infection differential
Elevated in majority of PCNSL cases (>60%); reflects leptomeningeal involvement and BBB disruption
Lumbar Puncture.target: Normal 15-45 mg/dL; often elevated (50-200+ mg/dL) in PCNSL

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Low in leptomeningeal disease; infection differential
Lumbar Puncture.target: Normal (>60% serum); may be low with extensive leptomeningeal involvement

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Malignant lymphocytes from leptomeningeal dissemination; positive in 15-30% of PCNSL
Lumbar Puncture.target: Large atypical lymphocytes; sensitivity improves with repeat LP and larger volume

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Most sensitive method for detecting clonal B-cell population in CSF; mandatory in PCNSL workup
Lumbar Puncture.target: Monoclonal B-cell population (CD19+, CD20+, surface light chain restricted); sensitivity higher than cytology

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Oligoclonal bands may be present; helps differentiate from MS and other inflammatory conditions
Lumbar Puncture.target: Absent oligoclonal bands favors lymphoma over MS; if present, does not exclude lymphoma

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: HIV-positive patients: high specificity for PCNSL when combined with compatible imaging; may avoid biopsy if clinical picture concordant
Lumbar Puncture.target: Positive in HIV-associated PCNSL; negative does not exclude

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Emerging diagnostic biomarker; present in ~70-80% of PCNSL; supports diagnosis when tissue is limited
Lumbar Puncture.target: Positive supports PCNSL diagnosis; false negative in ~20-30%

Essential/First-line.timing: Immediately upon presentation; first-line for acute symptoms (seizure, headache, focal deficit, altered mental status)
Essential/First-line.target: Hyperdense (because highly cellular) periventricular mass; may show hemorrhage (rare); edema; midline shift; usually homogeneous without ring enhancement

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (gadolinium) (CPT 70553)
Essential/First-line.timing: Within 24h of presentation; GOLD STANDARD for PCNSL diagnosis and characterization
Essential/First-line.target: Homogeneously enhancing periventricular or deep white matter mass; T1 iso/hypointense, T2 iso/hypointense; restricted diffusion on DWI (bright DWI, dark ADC); typically involves corpus callosum, basal ganglia, periventricular regions; multifocal in 25-50%; ring enhancement suggests immunocompromised (HIV)
Essential/First-line.contraindications: MRI-incompatible implants; GFR <30 (gadolinium risk); severe claustrophobia

Essential/First-line.timing: Within 48-72h; systemic staging to exclude secondary CNS lymphoma from systemic disease
Essential/First-line.target: No extracranial lymphoma; absence of lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, or other organ involvement confirms primary CNS disease

Essential/First-line.timing: Within 1-2 weeks; preferred over CT for systemic staging per IPCG guidelines; more sensitive for occult systemic lymphoma
Essential/First-line.target: No extracranial FDG-avid lymphoma; CNS lesions may or may not show FDG uptake (skull limits sensitivity for brain lesions)

Essential/First-line.timing: Pre-operative and pre-chemotherapy baseline; QTc for anti-emetics

Essential/First-line.target: No lung mass; no effusion; no mediastinal lymphadenopathy

Extended.timing: With initial MRI; critical for differential diagnosis
Extended.target: Restricted diffusion (bright DWI, dark ADC) = PCNSL (highly cellular tumor); GBM necrotic center does NOT restrict; abscess center DOES restrict
Extended.contraindications: MRI-incompatible implants; GFR <30 (gadolinium risk); severe claustrophobia

Extended.timing: With diagnostic MRI; differentiates from high-grade glioma
Extended.target: Lower rCBV than GBM (PCNSL has lower vascularity); moderate rCBV elevation compared to normal brain
Extended.contraindications: MRI-incompatible implants; GFR <30 (gadolinium risk); severe claustrophobia

Extended.target: Elevated choline (highly cellular); elevated lipid and lactate peaks; reduced NAA; high Cho/Cr ratio; large lipid peak more prominent than in GBM
Extended.contraindications: MRI-incompatible implants; GFR <30 (gadolinium risk); severe claustrophobia

Extended.timing: Within 1 week of diagnosis; mandatory staging per IPCG; 15-25% of PCNSL has occular involvement
Extended.target: Vitreous cells, subretinal infiltrates, or retinal/vitreal lymphoma deposits indicating intraocular involvement; changes management if positive

Extended.timing: If spinal symptoms present or CSF positive for lymphoma cells; leptomeningeal staging
Extended.target: Leptomeningeal enhancement; nerve root thickening; intramedullary lesion (rare)
Extended.contraindications: MRI-incompatible implants; GFR <30 (gadolinium risk); severe claustrophobia

Extended.timing: Staging per IPCG guidelines; testis is a sanctuary site; concurrent testicular lymphoma in 2-5%
Extended.target: No testicular mass; if present, changes staging and treatment approach

Extended.timing: Baseline cardiac function before anthracycline-containing regimens or high-dose chemotherapy with ASCT
Extended.target: LVEF >50%; adequate cardiac function for chemotherapy

Rare/Specialized.timing: When MRI equivocal; recurrence vs. treatment effect
Rare/Specialized.target: Increased FDG uptake in lymphoma (highly metabolic); helps differentiate recurrence from treatment-related changes

Rare/Specialized.timing: Staging per IPCG guidelines; rule out occult systemic lymphoma
Rare/Specialized.target: No lymphoma involvement; if positive, reclassify as systemic lymphoma with CNS involvement (different treatment)

Rare/Specialized.timing: If slit lamp exam shows vitreous cells or subretinal infiltrates suggesting intraocular lymphoma
Rare/Specialized.target: Cytology positive for large B-cells; flow cytometry showing monoclonal B-cell population; IL-10/IL-6 ratio >1.0 in vitreous fluid

Rare/Specialized.timing: HIV-positive patients: differentiates PCNSL from toxoplasmosis when imaging equivocal and biopsy not feasible
Rare/Specialized.target: Increased thallium uptake = PCNSL; decreased uptake = toxoplasmosis

Acute/Emergent.item: Dexamethasone (ONLY if life-threatening herniation or biopsy not immediately available)
Acute/Emergent.indication: Vasogenic edema with herniation risk or severe mass effect ONLY when biopsy cannot be performed within 24-48h; steroids cause rapid tumor regression making biopsy non-diagnostic

doseOptions.orderSentence: Dexamethasone (ONLY if life-threatening herniation or biopsy not immediately available) 10 mg IV

dosing.instructions: 10 mg IV bolus, then 4 mg IV/PO q6h; use LOWEST effective dose for SHORTEST duration; document that steroids were given and inform neurosurgeon and neuro-oncologist; biopsy should proceed ASAP even after steroids (may need repeat biopsy if non-diagnostic)
dosing.orderSentence: Dexamethasone (ONLY if life-threatening herniation or biopsy not immediately available) 10 mg IV

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: AVOID BEFORE BIOPSY whenever possible (causes vanishing tumor); active untreated infection; uncontrolled diabetes (relative)
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Glucose q6h (target <180 mg/dL), BP, document timing relative to biopsy, neurologic exam improvement (may confirm lymphoma diagnosis clinically)

Acute/Emergent.indication: Acute seizure termination; 10-20% of PCNSL patients present with seizures

dosing.instructions: 0.1 mg/kg IV (max 4 mg/dose); may repeat x1 in 5 min; max 8 mg total

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Acute narrow-angle glaucoma; severe respiratory depression without ventilator
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: RR, O2 sat, BP, sedation level; airway equipment at bedside

Acute/Emergent.indication: Anti-seizure medication loading for new seizures; preferred in CNS lymphoma patients due to no CYP enzyme induction (preserves chemotherapy efficacy)

dosing.instructions: 1000-1500 mg IV load, then 500-1500 mg PO/IV BID; renal dosing if GFR <50

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: None absolute; reduce dose if CrCl <50
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Behavioral changes (agitation, irritability); generally well tolerated

Acute/Emergent.indication: Acute elevated ICP with herniation signs; bridge to biopsy and definitive treatment

dosing.instructions: 1-1.5 g/kg IV bolus over 15-20 min; may repeat 0.25-0.5 g/kg q4-6h; maintain serum osmolality <320 mOsm/kg

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Anuria; severe dehydration; active intracranial bleeding (relative)
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Serum osmolality q6h, serum sodium, I/O, renal function

Acute/Emergent.indication: Acute elevated ICP; alternative to mannitol; may be preferred in hypotensive patients

dosing.instructions: 23.4% NaCl 30 mL via central line over 15 min OR 3% NaCl 250 mL IV over 30 min; target Na 145-155 mEq/L

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Sodium q4-6h, serum osmolality, I/O, central line required for 23.4%

Acute/Emergent.indication: Definitive tissue diagnosis; gold standard for PCNSL diagnosis; target enhancing component of lesion; AVOID open craniotomy/resection (no survival benefit from debulking in PCNSL unlike GBM)

dosing.instructions: Frame-based or frameless stereotactic biopsy; target enhancing tumor component; tissue for histology, immunohistochemistry (CD20, Ki-67, MUM1, BCL6), and flow cytometry; send for molecular studies (MYD88, CD79B)

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Active coagulopathy (correct first); location precluding safe biopsy (deep brainstem); prior steroids may reduce diagnostic yield (proceed anyway but warn pathologist)
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Post-biopsy CT within 6h; neurologic checks q1h x 24h; hemorrhage risk 1-3%

Acute/Emergent.indication: Lymphoma patients have elevated VTE risk; SCDs immediately; pharmacologic prophylaxis within 24-48h post-biopsy

dosing.instructions: Enoxaparin 40 mg SC daily or heparin 5000 units SC q8h; start within 24-48h post-biopsy per neurosurgery; SCDs until ambulatory

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Active intracranial hemorrhage; planned biopsy within 24h

Acute/Emergent.indication: GI bleed prevention while on dexamethasone (if steroids were initiated); combined corticosteroid + critical illness increases risk

dosing.instructions: Pantoprazole 40 mg IV/PO daily OR omeprazole 20 mg PO daily; continue throughout steroid course

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Seizure prevention after first seizure; NO prophylactic AEDs in patients without seizures; preferred due to no drug interactions with chemotherapy

dosing.instructions: Start 500 mg BID; titrate by 500 mg/day q1-2 weeks to seizure control; max 3000 mg/day; renal dosing if GFR <50

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: None absolute; reduce dose if CrCl <50
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Behavioral changes (agitation, depression, irritability), somnolence; no drug interactions with methotrexate or rituximab

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Alternative or adjunct AED for seizures; minimal drug interactions with chemotherapy

dosing.instructions: Start 50 mg BID; titrate by 50 mg/dose weekly; max 400 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: PR interval >200 ms; 2nd/3rd degree AV block; severe hepatic impairment
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: ECG at baseline and with dose changes; PR interval monitoring

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Nausea/vomiting from elevated ICP, chemotherapy (methotrexate, cytarabine), or radiation

dosing.instructions: 4-8 mg IV/PO q8h PRN nausea; max 24 mg/day; give 30 min before chemotherapy

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: QT prolongation; concurrent use of QT-prolonging agents
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: QTc if risk factors; serotonin syndrome risk with SSRIs

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Headache from elevated ICP or mass effect; avoid NSAIDs peri-biopsy due to bleeding risk; avoid NSAIDs during methotrexate therapy (impairs renal MTX clearance)

dosing.instructions: 650-1000 mg PO q6h PRN headache; max 3 g/day (2 g/day if hepatic impairment)

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Transition from IV to PO after biopsy obtained; taper as soon as clinically feasible; PCNSL often dramatically steroid-responsive; rapid taper once chemotherapy begins (MTX preferred without steroids)

dosing.instructions: Taper by 2 mg every 3-5 days (e.g., 16 to 12 to 8 to 6 to 4 to 2 to 1 to off); PCNSL may regrow during taper; definitive chemotherapy should start before taper is complete if possible

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Symptom recurrence during taper (may need slower taper or earlier chemotherapy)
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Glucose, BP, mood, steroid myopathy, immunosuppression, osteoporosis risk

dosing.instructions: Fingerstick glucose q6h; sliding scale insulin initially; basal-bolus if persistently >180 mg/dL; may need 2-3x baseline insulin on dexamethasone

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Pneumocystis prophylaxis during chemotherapy-induced immunosuppression; especially important given rituximab-induced B-cell depletion and chemotherapy-induced lymphopenia

dosing.instructions: TMP-SMX 1 DS tablet 3x/week (Mon/Wed/Fri) during chemotherapy and for 3-6 months after; continue if CD4 <200

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Sulfa allergy (use atovaquone 1500 mg daily or dapsone 100 mg daily as alternatives); renal impairment (dose adjust)
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: CBC; renal function; rash (Stevens-Johnson risk); hold during methotrexate infusion (interferes with MTX excretion)

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Herpes prophylaxis during immunosuppressive chemotherapy; rituximab increases reactivation risk

dosing.instructions: Acyclovir 400 mg PO BID or valacyclovir 500 mg PO daily; continue during chemotherapy and 3-6 months after completion

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Renal function; signs of viral reactivation

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Chemotherapy-induced neutropenia prevention or treatment; used with dose-dense methotrexate regimens to maintain treatment intensity

dosing.instructions: 5 mcg/kg SC daily starting 24-48h after chemotherapy until ANC >1500; pegfilgrastim 6 mg SC x1 dose alternative (not with MTX due to timing)

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: CBC daily during neutropenic phase; bone pain (common); spleen size if prolonged use

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Steroid-induced osteoporosis prevention while on prolonged dexamethasone; especially important with multiple steroid courses

doseOptions.orderSentence: Calcium + Vitamin D 1000 mg Ca + 800 IU Vit D PO

dosing.instructions: Calcium 1000-1200 mg + Vitamin D 800-1000 IU daily while on steroids
dosing.orderSentence: Calcium + Vitamin D 1000 mg Ca + 800 IU Vit D PO

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Cancer-related fatigue and cognitive slowing from tumor, chemotherapy, or radiation; may improve alertness during treatment

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg PO BID (morning and noon); titrate by 5 mg/dose q3-7 days; max 40 mg/day; avoid evening dosing

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Uncontrolled hypertension; tachyarrhythmia; severe anxiety; concurrent MAO inhibitors; glaucoma
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Heart rate, BP, appetite, sleep quality, mood (agitation)

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Relapsed/refractory PCNSL; excellent CNS penetration; especially effective if MYD88 L265P mutation present; single agent or with MTX-based regimen

dosing.instructions: 560 mg PO daily continuously until progression or intolerable toxicity; take at same time daily; avoid strong CYP3A4 inhibitors/inducers

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Active bleeding; requires dose modification with CYP3A4 inhibitors; atrial fibrillation risk; warfarin contraindicated (use DOACs)
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: CBC weekly x4 then monthly; LFTs monthly; ECG for atrial fibrillation; bleeding assessment; infection monitoring; hold 3-7 days before/after procedures

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Relapsed/refractory PCNSL after HD-MTX failure; oral alkylating agent with CNS penetration

dosing.instructions: 150-200 mg/m2 PO days 1-5 of 28-day cycle; take on empty stomach 1h before bed; antiemetic pre-medication

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Severe myelosuppression; prior temozolomide intolerance; hypersensitivity to dacarbazine
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: CBC Day 1 and Day 22 of each cycle; LFTs monthly; watch for lymphopenia and opportunistic infections

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Relapsed/refractory PCNSL; immunomodulatory agent; may combine with rituximab (R2 regimen)

dosing.instructions: 25 mg PO days 1-21 of 28-day cycle (21 days on, 7 days off); requires REMS enrollment (Revlimid REMS); thromboprophylaxis required

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Pregnancy (teratogenic, Category X); DVT/PE history (requires prophylaxis); neutropenia (ANC <1000); renal impairment (dose reduce)
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: CBC weekly x8 then monthly; pregnancy testing monthly (female patients); LFTs; renal function; TSH q3 months; VTE monitoring; REMS compliance

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Relapsed/refractory PCNSL; antifolate with CNS activity; single agent or combination

dosing.instructions: 900 mg/m2 IV over 10 min q3 weeks; supplement with folic acid 1 mg PO daily and B12 1000 mcg IM q9 weeks (start 7 days before first dose); dexamethasone 4 mg PO BID x3 days starting day before pemetrexed

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: CrCl <45; inability to take folic acid/B12 supplementation; pleural effusion (3rd space - delays clearance)
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: CBC weekly; renal function; LFTs; rash; signs of toxicity; folic acid and B12 compliance

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Relapsed/refractory PCNSL; topoisomerase I inhibitor with CNS penetration

dosing.instructions: 1.5 mg/m2 IV daily x 5 days every 21 days; dose reduce for renal impairment or myelosuppression

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Severe myelosuppression (ANC <1500, platelets <100K); severe renal impairment
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: CBC with differential before each cycle; nadir at day 11; renal function; signs of infection during neutropenic period

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Relapsed/refractory PCNSL after HD-MTX failure; salvage option; avoid if possible in patients who may be candidates for re-challenge with chemotherapy; significant neurotoxicity risk especially in elderly (>60)

dosing.instructions: 23.4 Gy in 13 fractions (1.8 Gy/fraction) reduced-dose WBRT per RTOG 1114; OR 36-45 Gy in 20-25 fractions (higher dose if used as sole therapy); consider omission in patients >60 due to severe neurocognitive toxicity risk

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Prior full-dose WBRT; pregnancy; age >60 (relative, due to neurotoxicity)
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Neurocognitive testing at baseline and q3 months; MRI q2-3 months; watch for delayed leukoencephalopathy (may develop 6-12 months post-RT); neurotoxicity screening

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Induction C.indication: CORNERSTONE of PCNSL treatment; first-line induction; achieves therapeutic CNS concentrations; administered as part of multi-agent regimen (R-MPV, MATRix, DeAngelis protocol); 60-80% overall response rate

dosing.instructions: 3.5 g/m2 IV over 4 hours; aggressive IV hydration (2-3 L/m2) starting 12h before and continuing 48h after; urine alkalinization with sodium bicarbonate (target pH >7.0); leucovorin rescue starting 24h after MTX completion (25 mg IV/PO q6h until MTX level <0.05 micromol/L); q2 week cycles x 5-7 based on response; hold TMP-SMX during MTX weeks

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Induction C.pretreatment: CrCl >50 mL/min (essential); no third-space fluid collections (ascites, pleural effusion - delays MTX clearance); CBC (ANC >1000, platelets >75K); LFTs normal; urine pH >7.0 before infusion; hepatitis B cleared or on prophylaxis; adequate hydration status; no concurrent nephrotoxic drugs (NSAIDs, aminoglycosides)
Disease-Modifying Therapies (Induction C.contraindications: CrCl <50 mL/min; third-space fluid (ascites, large pleural effusion); concurrent nephrotoxic drugs including NSAIDs; active infection; severe hepatic impairment; pregnancy
Disease-Modifying Therapies (Induction C.monitoring: Serum MTX levels at 24h, 48h, 72h (and until <0.05 micromol/L); creatinine q12h during infusion and for 72h after; urine output (target >100 mL/h); urine pH q6h (maintain >7.0); CBC with differential; LFTs; mucositis assessment; neurologic exam

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Induction C.indication: Anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody; combined with HD-MTX in R-MPV and MATRix regimens; PCNSL is CD20+ in >95% of cases; improves response rate when combined with MTX-based chemotherapy

dosing.instructions: 375 mg/m2 IV; first infusion: start at 50 mg/h, increase by 50 mg/h q30min to max 400 mg/h; subsequent infusions: start at 100 mg/h, increase by 100 mg/h q30min to max 400 mg/h; administer per protocol schedule (typically Day 1 of each cycle); premedicate with acetaminophen 650 mg, diphenhydramine 50 mg, and methylprednisolone 100 mg IV

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Induction C.pretreatment: Hepatitis B screening completed (HBsAg, anti-HBc, anti-HBs); CBC; baseline immunoglobulins; premedication protocol; cardiac function assessment
Disease-Modifying Therapies (Induction C.contraindications: Active HBV infection without antiviral prophylaxis (fatal reactivation risk); severe active infection; severe cardiac disease (arrhythmia risk with infusion); known hypersensitivity
Disease-Modifying Therapies (Induction C.monitoring: Infusion reaction monitoring (vitals q15min during first infusion, q30min subsequent); HBV DNA if core antibody positive (q3 months); quantitative immunoglobulins q3 months; signs of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML)

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Induction C.indication: Component of R-MPV regimen (Rituximab, Methotrexate, Procarbazine, Vincristine); alkylating agent with CNS penetration

dosing.instructions: 100 mg/m2 PO daily x 7 days on odd-numbered cycles (cycles 1, 3, 5); take on empty stomach; tyramine-free diet during and 2 weeks after (MAO inhibitor properties)

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Induction C.pretreatment: Concurrent MAO inhibitors, SSRIs, SNRIs, meperidine, sympathomimetics; tyramine-rich foods (aged cheese, wine, fermented foods); severe myelosuppression; severe hepatic/renal impairment
Disease-Modifying Therapies (Induction C.contraindications: CBC before each cycle; LFTs; educate on dietary restrictions (tyramine); signs of peripheral neuropathy; rash (allergic dermatitis common, may require discontinuation)

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Induction C.indication: Component of R-MPV regimen; vinca alkaloid; contributes to multi-agent synergy

dosing.instructions: 1.4 mg/m2 IV push (max 2 mg per dose) on Day 1 of each cycle; NEVER administer intrathecally (fatal); vesicant - administer through running IV

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Induction C.pretreatment: Pre-existing severe peripheral neuropathy; Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease; demyelinating conditions; NEVER intrathecal (fatal)
Disease-Modifying Therapies (Induction C.contraindications: Peripheral neuropathy assessment before each dose (grade and hold if Grade 3+); constipation (autonomic neuropathy); jaw pain; ileus monitoring; foot drop assessment

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Induction C.indication: Component of MATRix regimen (MTX, Ara-C, Thiotepa, Rituximab); high-dose achieves therapeutic CSF levels; consolidation in younger patients

dosing.orderSentence: Cytarabine (high-dose, MATRix regimen component) 2 g/m2 IV

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Induction C.pretreatment: Age >60 (increased cerebellar toxicity risk); cerebellar dysfunction; renal impairment (CrCl <60 - dose reduce); hepatic impairment

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Induction C.item: Thiotepa (MATRix regimen component or ASCT conditioning)

dosing.instructions: 30 mg/m2 IV over 15-30 min on Day 4 of each MATRix cycle; for ASCT conditioning: higher doses per transplant protocol
dosing.orderSentence: Thiotepa (MATRix regimen component or ASCT conditioning) 30 mg/m2 IV

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Induction C.contraindications: CBC (profound myelosuppression expected); mucositis; skin toxicity (rash, hyperpigmentation); LFTs; signs of VOD with high-dose conditioning

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Induction C.indication: Consolidation after chemotherapy induction; REDUCED dose (23.4 Gy) after CR to HD-MTX per RTOG 1114; previously full dose (45 Gy) but reduced due to neurotoxicity; alternative: ASCT consolidation

dosing.instructions: 23.4 Gy in 13 fractions (1.8 Gy/fraction) for patients in CR after HD-MTX induction; 45 Gy in 25 fractions for partial responders; begin 4-6 weeks after last chemotherapy cycle; consider omission in patients >60 due to delayed neurotoxicity risk

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Induction C.pretreatment: Prior WBRT; pregnancy; age >60 (relative contraindication - consider ASCT or observation instead)
Disease-Modifying Therapies (Induction C.contraindications: Neurocognitive testing at baseline and q3-6 months post-RT; MRI q2-3 months; watch for delayed leukoencephalopathy; neurotoxicity risk increases with age and cumulative MTX exposure

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Induction C.item: High-dose chemotherapy with autologous stem cell transplant (HDC-ASCT)
Disease-Modifying Therapies (Induction C.indication: Consolidation alternative to WBRT; preferred in younger patients (age <65-70) to avoid radiation neurotoxicity; thiotepa-based conditioning regimen most common for PCNSL

doseOptions.orderSentence: High-dose chemotherapy with autologous stem cell transplant (HDC-ASCT) Thiotepa-based conditioning IV

dosing.instructions: Stem cell mobilization after induction CR; conditioning: thiotepa 5 mg/kg IV x2 days + carmustine (BCNU) 400 mg/m2 IV x1 day (or other institutional protocol); autologous stem cell infusion Day 0; requires transplant-capable center
dosing.orderSentence: High-dose chemotherapy with autologous stem cell transplant (HDC-ASCT) Thiotepa-based conditioning IV

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Induction C.pretreatment: Age >70 (relative); KPS <60; inadequate stem cell collection; active infection; organ dysfunction (cardiac, pulmonary, hepatic, renal)
Disease-Modifying Therapies (Induction C.contraindications: Engraftment monitoring (ANC, platelets); infection prophylaxis; mucositis; hepatic VOD screening; renal function; pulmonary function; MRI q3 months post-transplant

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Induction C.indication: Positive CSF cytology/flow cytometry; leptomeningeal involvement documented; administered via lumbar puncture or Ommaya reservoir; role diminished with HD-MTX (which achieves therapeutic CSF levels)

dosing.instructions: 12 mg IT (preservative-free) via LP or Ommaya reservoir; 2x/week for 4 weeks, then weekly x4-8 weeks, then monthly; reconstitute in preservative-free normal saline; give with leucovorin 10 mg PO q6h x 4 doses starting 24h after IT MTX

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Induction C.pretreatment: Active CNS infection; elevated ICP with herniation risk; LP contraindications
Disease-Modifying Therapies (Induction C.contraindications: Opening pressure before each IT injection; neurologic exam (arachnoiditis, myelopathy); MTX neurotoxicity symptoms; concurrent systemic MTX timing (avoid within 48h)

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Induction C.indication: HIV-positive patients: ART is critical component of treatment; immune reconstitution may independently cause tumor regression; start concurrently with chemotherapy or before if CD4 critically low

doseOptions.orderSentence: ART initiation (HIV-associated PCNSL) Per HIV guidelines PO

dosing.instructions: Preferred: bictegravir/emtricitabine/TAF (Biktarvy) 1 tablet PO daily or dolutegravir-based regimen; check for drug interactions with chemotherapy; avoid protease inhibitors (CYP interactions with chemotherapy); INSTI-based regimens preferred
dosing.orderSentence: ART initiation (HIV-associated PCNSL) Per HIV guidelines PO

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Induction C.pretreatment: Check drug-drug interactions with chemotherapy regimen; avoid strong CYP3A4 inhibitors
Disease-Modifying Therapies (Induction C.contraindications: CD4 count and HIV viral load at baseline and q3 months; drug interaction review with each chemotherapy cycle; IRIS monitoring (immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome may cause paradoxical worsening)

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurosurgery STAT consultation for stereotactic biopsy planning; emphasize AVOID open resection (no survival benefit in PCNSL, unlike gliomas); biopsy should proceed before steroids if possible
Neuro-oncology consultation for HD-MTX-based chemotherapy planning, response assessment, and long-term management
Hematology/oncology consultation for lymphoma staging, systemic evaluation, and consideration of ASCT consolidation in eligible patients
Radiation oncology consultation for consolidation WBRT planning or salvage radiation therapy; discuss reduced-dose WBRT (23.4 Gy) vs. ASCT consolidation options
Ophthalmology consultation with dilated slit lamp examination for all PCNSL patients to evaluate for intraocular lymphoma (15-25% prevalence) as this changes staging and may require ocular radiation
Multidisciplinary tumor board presentation for coordinated treatment planning including neurosurgery, neuro-oncology, hematology, radiation oncology, neuropathology, and neuroradiology
Neuropathology consultation for comprehensive tissue analysis including CD20, CD79a, MUM1, BCL6, Ki-67, MYD88 L265P mutation, and CD79B mutation to confirm DLBCL and identify actionable targets
Infectious disease consultation for HIV-positive patients for ART optimization, opportunistic infection prophylaxis, and drug interaction management with chemotherapy

Palliative care consultation for symptom management, goals of care discussion, and advance directive completion given median survival of 2-5 years (immunocompetent) or shorter (HIV-associated without ART)
Physical therapy for mobility assessment, fall prevention given neurologic deficits and steroid myopathy, and exercise program to mitigate chemotherapy-related deconditioning
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment, cognitive compensation strategies, and home safety evaluation
Speech-language pathology for swallow evaluation if posterior fossa involvement, and language/cognitive assessment if dominant hemisphere tumor
Social work consultation for insurance authorization (HD-MTX requires frequent hospitalization), disability paperwork, caregiver support, and community resources
Neuropsychology evaluation for baseline cognitive assessment before radiation or transplant to monitor for treatment-related neurotoxicity
Psychiatry/psychology referral for depression, anxiety, and adjustment disorder management given cancer diagnosis and cognitive symptoms
Fertility counseling in reproductive-age patients before chemotherapy initiation as methotrexate, procarbazine, and alkylating agents may cause infertility
Transplant evaluation consultation for patients under age 65-70 who achieve CR to induction chemotherapy and are candidates for HDC-ASCT consolidation
Clinical trials evaluation for eligible patients at all stages including newly diagnosed (novel combinations) and relapsed/refractory (BTK inhibitors, immunotherapy, CAR-T)

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately for new or worsening headache, sudden weakness, vision changes, speech difficulty, or seizures (may indicate tumor progression or increased intracranial pressure)
Return immediately for fever >100.4F, chills, or signs of infection during chemotherapy as this may indicate life-threatening neutropenic sepsis requiring emergency evaluation
Do not drive until cleared by neurology due to seizure risk, visual changes, and cognitive impairment from tumor and treatment
Do not stop dexamethasone abruptly (if prescribed) as this may cause adrenal crisis; follow prescribed taper schedule exactly
Report any mouth sores, difficulty swallowing, or abdominal pain during methotrexate treatment as mucositis requires early intervention
Maintain excellent oral hydration (2-3 L/day unless restricted) during methotrexate treatment to promote renal clearance and reduce nephrotoxicity
Avoid NSAIDs (ibuprofen, naproxen, aspirin) during methotrexate treatment as these impair methotrexate excretion and increase toxicity risk
Avoid alcohol during chemotherapy to prevent hepatotoxicity and to avoid seizure threshold lowering
Report any visual changes (blurred vision, floaters, eye pain) as these may indicate intraocular lymphoma involvement requiring ophthalmologic evaluation
Keep a symptom diary documenting headaches, seizures, weakness, cognitive changes, vision changes, and mood to track treatment response
Discuss advance directive and healthcare proxy designation given diagnosis and treatment complexity
Wear medical alert identification indicating cancer diagnosis, seizure risk, and immunosuppressed status
Avoid live vaccines during and for 6 months after chemotherapy and rituximab due to immunosuppression
If taking procarbazine: avoid tyramine-rich foods (aged cheese, cured meats, red wine, soy sauce, fermented foods) as this can cause hypertensive crisis (MAO inhibitor properties)

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Low-sodium diet while on dexamethasone to reduce fluid retention, edema, and hypertension
Blood sugar monitoring and diabetic diet while on steroids to prevent steroid-induced hyperglycemia complications
Regular low-impact exercise (walking, swimming, yoga) as tolerated to maintain strength, reduce steroid myopathy, and improve mood and quality of life
Fall precautions at home including removal of trip hazards, use of handrails, non-slip mats, and night lights given neurologic deficits, steroid myopathy, and seizure risk
Smoking cessation to optimize wound healing, immune function, and reduce thrombotic risk during chemotherapy
Alcohol avoidance during chemotherapy to prevent hepatotoxicity and avoid seizure threshold lowering
Sun protection during chemotherapy and methotrexate treatment due to photosensitivity risk
Adequate hydration (2-3 L/day unless fluid restricted) especially critical during methotrexate treatment weeks to support renal function
Nutritious high-protein diet to support immune function and maintain weight during chemotherapy; dietitian referral if weight loss >5%
Hand hygiene and infection avoidance measures (avoid crowds, sick contacts) during immunosuppressive chemotherapy

differential.features: Ring-enhancing (vs. homogeneous in PCNSL); central necrosis (common in GBM, rare in immunocompetent PCNSL); irregular thick rim; hemorrhagic; typically single; does NOT restrict on DWI centrally; does NOT respond dramatically to steroids
differential.tests: MRI with DWI (PCNSL restricts, GBM necrosis does not); MR perfusion (GBM has higher rCBV); steroid response (dramatic in PCNSL); stereotactic biopsy (GFAP+ in GBM, CD20+ in PCNSL)

differential.features: History of systemic malignancy; multiple lesions at gray-white junction; well-demarcated ring enhancement; less periventricular predilection; known primary cancer
differential.tests: CT chest/abdomen/pelvis; PET/CT for primary site; biopsy with immunohistochemistry for primary site markers (TTF-1, CK7/20, HER2, melanoma markers)

differential.features: HIV/AIDS with CD4 <100; multiple ring-enhancing lesions; basal ganglia predilection; eccentric target sign; positive Toxoplasma IgG in >90%; responds to empiric treatment in 10-14 days
differential.tests: Toxoplasma IgG (positive in >90% of toxo, but also common in general population); empiric treatment trial with pyrimethamine + sulfadiazine (10-14 days); if no improvement then biopsy; Thallium SPECT (cold in toxo, hot in lymphoma)

differential.features: Younger patients; leptomeningeal enhancement pattern; cranial nerve palsies (especially CN VII); pulmonary involvement (hilar lymphadenopathy); elevated ACE; non-caseating granulomas
differential.tests: Chest CT (hilar lymphadenopathy); serum ACE; CSF ACE; PET/CT for systemic sarcoidosis; tissue biopsy showing non-caseating granulomas (vs. large B-cells in PCNSL)

differential.features: Younger patients; incomplete ring enhancement ("open ring sign"); less mass effect relative to size; clinical dissemination in time and space; other demyelinating lesions
differential.tests: MRI: open ring enhancement; CSF oligoclonal bands; MOG/AQP4 antibodies; clinical dissemination criteria; biopsy showing demyelination (not lymphoma)

differential.features: Immunocompromised (HIV, natalizumab, rituximab); non-enhancing white matter lesions (unlike PCNSL which enhances); no mass effect; JC virus-mediated
differential.tests: CSF JC virus PCR (positive); non-enhancing pattern; no restricted diffusion (vs. PCNSL which restricts); brain biopsy if PCR negative but clinical suspicion high

differential.features: Ring-enhancing with central restricted diffusion on DWI (bright DWI in cavity center, similar to PCNSL); thin smooth rim (vs. thick irregular in PCNSL); fever, leukocytosis; source (dental, ENT, cardiac)
differential.tests: DWI (both PCNSL and abscess restrict, but abscess cavity center restricts while PCNSL is solid); MR spectroscopy (amino acid peaks in abscess: succinate, acetate, not present in lymphoma); blood cultures; echocardiogram

differential.features: Subacute cognitive/behavioral changes; limbic involvement; seizures; autoantibodies (NMDAR, LGI1, CASPR2); less mass effect; often non-enhancing or mildly enhancing
differential.tests: Autoimmune encephalitis antibody panel (serum and CSF); EEG (extreme delta brush in NMDAR); MRI pattern (medial temporal, less mass effect); CSF lymphocytic pleocytosis without malignant cells

differential.features: Multifocal white matter lesions; may enhance; headache; cognitive decline; vessel wall enhancement on VWI; stroke-like episodes
differential.tests: MRA/CTA (beading, stenosis); vessel wall imaging (concentric enhancement); ESR/CRP; angiography (classic beading pattern); brain and leptomeningeal biopsy showing vasculitis (not lymphoma)

differential.features: Rare B-cell lymphoma confined to blood vessel lumens; multifocal strokes; diffuse white matter disease; skin involvement; no discrete mass on imaging (unlike PCNSL)
differential.tests: Random skin biopsy (positive in 70-80%); brain biopsy showing intravascular large B-cells; MRI pattern (punctate enhancing lesions, diffuse white matter changes, stroke-like pattern)

evidence.recommendation: High-dose methotrexate (>=3 g/m2) is the backbone of PCNSL induction therapy
Combination of HD-MTX with rituximab improves outcomes in PCNSL (IELSG #32); MATRix regimen (MTX, Ara-C, Thiotepa, Rituximab) is effective induction for PCNSL
R-MPV regimen (Rituximab, Methotrexate, Procarbazine, Vincristine) followed by reduced-dose WBRT
Reduced-dose WBRT (23.4 Gy) after CR to MTX-based chemotherapy preserves neurocognitive function (RTOG 1114)
WBRT omission with ASCT consolidation is noninferior to WBRT in younger patients
HDC-ASCT is effective consolidation for PCNSL with thiotepa-based conditioning
evidence.source: [Illerhaus et al. Blood 2016](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/27207798/); [Omuro et al. Blood 2015](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25568347/)

evidence.recommendation: Ibrutinib has CNS activity in relapsed/refractory PCNSL
Lenalidomide plus rituximab (R2) active in relapsed PCNSL
Corticosteroids cause vanishing tumor in PCNSL; avoid before biopsy
evidence.source: [Kuhlmann et al. Acta Neuropathol 2008](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18175128/); Expert consensus

evidence.recommendation: MYD88 L265P mutation present in ~70-80% of PCNSL; diagnostic and therapeutic target
IELSG prognostic scoring system for PCNSL (age, ECOG, LDH, CSF protein, deep brain involvement)
Slit lamp examination mandatory at diagnosis (15-25% ocular involvement)
NCCN Guidelines for CNS Cancers - Primary CNS Lymphoma section
EBV CSF PCR highly specific for HIV-associated PCNSL
Rituximab requires HBV screening before administration (fatal reactivation risk)
evidence.source: [FDA Black Box Warning]; [Evens et al. Blood 2011](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21653327/)

evidence.recommendation: Prophylactic AEDs NOT recommended in brain tumor patients without seizures
Levetiracetam preferred AED in CNS tumor patients (no CYP enzyme induction)
Pemetrexed active in relapsed PCNSL
CSF IL-10/IL-6 ratio >1.0 supports CNS lymphoma diagnosis
Temozolomide has activity in relapsed PCNSL
Thallium SPECT differentiates PCNSL from toxoplasmosis in HIV patients
Dexamethasone eye drops prevent cytarabine-induced chemical conjunctivitis
evidence.source: Expert consensus; [Cerci & Ostronoff J Clin Oncol 2014](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25422493/)

evidence.recommendation: Memorial Sloan Kettering prognostic model for PCNSL (age, KPS)

monitoring.item: Neurologic examination (motor, sensory, language, cognition, cranial nerves, visual fields)
monitoring.action: STAT MRI if decline; increase dexamethasone if post-biopsy; expedite chemotherapy initiation

monitoring.frequency: q6h while on dexamethasone (q1h if insulin drip)
monitoring.action: Sliding scale to basal-bolus insulin; endocrine consult if refractory

monitoring.frequency: q12h during MTX infusion and for 72h after; each cycle pre-treatment
monitoring.action: Delay MTX until CrCl recovers; aggressive hydration; glucarpidase if MTX level critically elevated with renal failure
Continue leucovorin rescue until level <0.05; if level >10 micromol/L at 48h with rising creatinine, consider glucarpidase

monitoring.frequency: q48h during MTX hospitalization; weekly between cycles; before each cycle Day 1
monitoring.action: Delay chemotherapy; G-CSF for neutropenia (ANC <1000); platelet transfusion if <10K or bleeding; neutropenic fever protocol if febrile with ANC <500

monitoring.frequency: q6h during MTX infusion and for 48h after
monitoring.action: Increase sodium bicarbonate infusion; hold MTX infusion if pH <7.0; recheck in 1h after bolus

monitoring.frequency: q1h during MTX infusion and for 48-72h after
monitoring.action: Increase IV fluids; furosemide if fluid overloaded but oliguria; STAT creatinine and MTX level

monitoring.frequency: q2 weeks during induction; monthly during consolidation
monitoring.action: Dose reduce or hold chemotherapy; hepatology consult if Grade 3-4 elevation

monitoring.frequency: q6-12h inpatient during IV hydration for MTX
monitoring.action: SIADH workup if <130; adjust hydration; hypertonic saline if <125 or symptomatic

monitoring.frequency: Post-biopsy CT within 6h; baseline MRI; after 2-3 cycles of induction; end of induction; then q2-3 months
monitoring.action: Tumor board discussion if progression; consider salvage therapy; rebiopsy if uncertain (pseudoprogression rare in PCNSL but can occur with immunotherapy)

monitoring.frequency: Baseline (mandatory); after induction; q3-6 months for 2 years; annually thereafter
monitoring.action: If new ocular involvement: ocular radiation therapy (30-36 Gy); intravitreal methotrexate; reassess systemic disease

monitoring.frequency: Baseline; q3 months during rituximab; q6 months after completion
monitoring.action: IVIG replacement if IgG <400 with recurrent infections; hold rituximab if severe hypogammaglobulinemia

monitoring.frequency: Baseline; q3 months during treatment; monthly if HIV-positive
monitoring.action: Maintain PJP and antiviral prophylaxis; dose adjustments; delay treatment if critically immunosuppressed with active infection

monitoring.frequency: Continuous in ICU; q4h on floor; each clinic visit
monitoring.action: Antihypertensives; especially important during aggressive hydration for MTX

monitoring.frequency: Baseline; 6 months post-treatment; annually (especially after WBRT)
monitoring.action: Neuropsychology referral; rehabilitation; consider memantine or cognitive rehabilitation; screen for delayed leukoencephalopathy after WBRT
KPS <40: reassess goals of care; transition to supportive care/hospice
Psychiatry/psychology referral; SSRI initiation (check drug interactions)

disposition.criteria: GCS <=12; signs of herniation (pupil asymmetry, posturing, Cushing triad); status epilepticus; methotrexate toxicity with acute renal failure requiring monitoring or glucarpidase; neutropenic sepsis with hemodynamic instability; tumor lysis syndrome; HDC-ASCT conditioning and engraftment period

New diagnosis requiring workup, biopsy, and staging; HD-MTX infusion cycles (typically 3-5 day admission per cycle for hydration, monitoring, leucovorin rescue); symptomatic edema requiring IV dexamethasone with close glucose monitoring; post-biopsy observation; seizures requiring AED optimization; functional decline requiring rehabilitation planning
Known PCNSL with mild symptom worsening on stable regimen; MRI showing possible progression requiring multidisciplinary discussion; steroid dose adjustment with monitoring

Neurologically stable for >=24h; seizure-free >=24h on oral AED; methotrexate level <0.05 micromol/L; creatinine stable; oral dexamethasone taper plan (if applicable); adequate oral hydration demonstrated; pain controlled on oral medications; treatment plan established with scheduled follow-up (neuro-oncology within 1-2 weeks); safe ambulation or adequate caregiver; patient/family education completed; neutropenic precaution education if ANC recovering
Need for neuro-oncology expertise with HD-MTX protocol; transplant-capable center for ASCT consolidation; clinical trial access; complex HIV co-management

Significant neurologic deficits (hemiparesis, aphasia, cognitive impairment) requiring intensive rehabilitation before outpatient treatment; KPS 40-60 with rehabilitation potential; coordination with ongoing chemotherapy schedule
Progressive PCNSL refractory to multiple lines of therapy; poor functional status (KPS <30); patient/family goals aligned with comfort-focused care; no longer candidate for disease-directed therapy
